text: “All my life I had the thing that makes my income, and the thing I loved. I went hard at both,” says @Al_Letson. “At night I come home, stay up for hours, write my screenplay.” #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: Poets, musicians telling great stories today? @Al_Letson: Go Ahead in the Rain: Notes to A Tribe Called Quest by Hanif Abdurraqib. My Mother Was a Freedom Fighter by Aja Monet. There Are More Beautiful Things Than Beyoncé by Morgan Parker. @chancetherapper @noname #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Career advice for young journalists? Consider nonprofit news such as @ProPublica, @reveal, says @Al_Letson. "Research them and bug 'em until you get in. If you get into an organization, show up, kick ass, be at your top game." #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: On newspapers' failures before the Iraq war, which @Al_Letson just mentioned -- here's the best single read on the subject (if you ask me): https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2004/02/26/now-they-tell-us/ …  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: About the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, which @Al_Letson just mentioned at #NarrativeBU:
author: ErickTrickey

text: Sometimes journalism has failed America, says @Al_Letson. A newspaper egged on the Tulsa race massacre of 1921. Newspapers egged on the 2003 war with Iraq. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "Every single one of us owes the future something," says @Al_Letson. "Let’s grasp the importance of what we do & who we are in these times."  #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: The history of redlining helps explain why young black men are killing each other in Chicago & other cities, says @Al_Letson. AND his show found redlining still happening NOW. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Impact & reaction from Valedictorians Project: 150 people turned out in a blizzard to talk about how it reflected their lives & possible solutions. No answer from Boston Public Schools, though superintendent praised it to @MeghanIrons.  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
Lessons learned by @MeghanIrons & @MalcolmGay on Valedictorians Project: Share notes; make sure you’re talking to each other. 
Formulate standard questions early.
Don’t be locked into a preconceived notion of the story, if your reporting is taking you elsewhere. 
#narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Editors at @BostonGlobe coordinated the Valedictorians Project’s many stories to make sure they weren’t repetitive. @MalcolmGay: You can only write about someone struggling in intro to chemistry so many times. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: To get data on former Boston valedictorians, @MeghanIrons & @malcolmgay gave some of them anonymity at first. But many wouldn’t go on the record months later. Looking back, they wish they'd negotiated harder to go on the record the first time. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: The former valedictorians' mini-bios:
author: ErickTrickey

text: Here's the @BostonGlobe Valedictorians Project, which @MeghanIrons & @malcolmgay are talking about right now at #narrativeBU --
author: ErickTrickey

text: Give your translator a notebook, says @sdooling. Ask them not to interrupt the interviewee.
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: How to work through translators? If they're a friend, from the community, they may take shortcuts in translation or be reluctant to ask certain questions.  @frantrianni. I invest time in building a relationship with the translators, teach them interviewing. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey
ErickTrickey

text: A student asks the all-female panel of immigration reporters: How do you persist when your voices aren't heard? @frantrianni & @mariasacchetti & @JacquiB encourage her & say: Report on women. Get women's stories a man couldn't get. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
Q: How do you cope when a story doesn’t have the impact you thought it would?
@sdooling -- "Don’t read the comments!" @AvoidComments #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: How to cover immigration at a smaller outlet? Sometimes smaller communities are easier to cover, says @sdooling. But it takes trust and time. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Sometimes you've got to tell the public what you can't find out, says @mariasacchetti. ICE will claim 90% of arrestees are criminal, but it can't be proven. Advocates will tell a story but won't give a name & case #. Both sides telling us only what they want told. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "Protecting a source is important," says @mariasacchetti. "Fully vetting them is also important." #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Story @mariasacchetti is talking about now at #narrativeBU -- He warned that death was waiting for him in Honduras. After getting deported, he turned up dead.
author: ErickTrickey

text: Reasons newspaper & magazine editors give for shortage of diversity in the profession aren't good enough, says Katherine Boo. "It shouldn't be a closed elite, a secret society." #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q from @laneyruckstuhl: Shouldn’t there also be more journalists from disadvantaged communities? Katherine Boo: “After my book, I wanted to edit, to support people not in the J-school circuit, including people in North Carolina & Nevada, not the Acela Corridor.” #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: How to get people to read about a slum, with no happy ending?  Dive into the middle of things, make it full of energy, Katherine Boo decided -- a novelistic choice. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Why Katherine Boo doesn’t choose 1st person, or like Qs about her reporting experiences: “There’s a whole history of writing about white ladies in scary places. I’d rather you read about people who don’t have a choice.” #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Matt Desmond to Kate Boo: How do you write about people so honestly, when every word could have political implications? A: I hope to write about you as my sister would write about me. Hopefully people will see you as your family sees you, knowing you’re not perfect. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: I agree.  Why not make it part of the COM curriculum?
author: ErickTrickey

text: There's a danger that narrative nonfiction churns out tragedy as entertainment, says Katherine Boo. If I only do stories of victims, I’m just doing poverty porn. You’ve got to write about the perps, the injustices affecting these communities. #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: #narrativeBU is $50 for students, but often my students still decide to volunteer so they can get in for free.
author: ErickTrickey

text: In the history of writing about poor communities, often the person whose voice comes out is the most hyperverbal, says Katherine Boo. So we have to practice a different kind of listening.  #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Katherine Boo videotapes as a reporter. If you get two things wrong, powerful people can question the story, she says. She doesn’t want people to say, the room wasn’t green, it was yellow. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "We need to build a scaffolding of documentary evidence around stories so they can’t be dismissed by powerful people." -Matthew Desmond #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Matt Desmond says a young woman told him she dropped out of school because of a shooting there. Her mom said it was true. But he called the schools -- no such shooting. What if he had published it? #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "People in powerless communities have a right to be written about as accurately as people in power," says Katherine Boo. That means using real names, fact-checking everyone, adds Matthew Desmond. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Trauma over the internet: What if someone calls you a bitch in an email? Or you get a death threat because you’re doing your job? @sarahrkess recommends the PEN America Online Harassment Field Manual: https://pen.org/online-harassment-field-manual/ … #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Social support is important after trauma, says @sarahrkess. Editors should encourage it. Consider police, who have traumatic incident debriefing teams. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: When anxiety spikes, @sarahrkess recommends combat tactical breathing, used by police & military. Breathe in 4 counts. Stop and hold breath 4 counts. Exhale 4 counts. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: A study showed journalists’ brains operate at a lower level than average population!  Because of dehydration, alcohol, diet with high amounts of caffeine, sugary foods! -@sarahrkess #NarrativeBU #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Journalists often say, “It didn’t affect me personally. That person is feeling way worse than I am,” says @sarahrkess. But there is no hierarchy of trauma. It’s valid and legitimate and deserves to be addressed.  #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: About 90% of journalists have been exposed to a work-related traumatic event, says @sarahrkess, citing the @DartCenter. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: “There are going to be consequences for seeing someone else’s suffering," says @sarahrkess, at her talk The Trauma of Journalism: Self-Care for Journalists.   #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: But we've got to go places where reporters aren't popular, @elisaslow says. "Otherwise, in this polarizing country, people not going to have chance to learn about the lives of people different from their own." #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "There's a natural inclination for institutions and people to cater to their audience," @elisaslow warns. @washingtonpost has seen explosive growth -- mostly in ideological parts of country that are not rural Oklahoma. #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "I’m not writing for them," says @elisaslow of the people he writes about. "It’s not my job. It’s also not true to say I don’t care what they think. It’s impossible not to care." #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "Hopefully trust builds over time, because you’re genuine and caring. But not caring in the sense you’re going to advocate." @elisaslow #narrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "I am not trying to write about them as an advocate," says @elisaslow. As soon as he does that, it hurts the journalism. #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: "My job has gotten harder," says @elisaslow. In places like rural Oklahoma, showing up as a reporter, especially for the @washingtonpost, not a great start. "Fake news," &c. "Often as a reporter I’m either canonized or demonized for reasons I don’t understand." #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: "I’d rather spend two weeks reporting, 4 days writing than 1 week reporting, 1½ weeks writing," says @elisaslow #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: How long does @elisaslow's immersion reporting take? A: Usually 2 trips, 4-5 days each. Sometimes shorter, 3 days. "If I have 3 hours of reporting, 3rd hour is inevitably the best hour. If 2 weeks, the 2nd week the best." #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: What’s @elisaslow's hit rate -- How often do people say no to being subjects of his immersion reporting? A: "I get told no a lot." For story about alcohol deaths in Oklahoma, "I got told no 5 times, dead end 5 times. That’s pretty typical." #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: At the start, @elisaslow tries to be really transparent about how long his immersion reporting takes. Otherwise, people will say, "You’ve been here a day now, & we’ve talked about this, & you still want to talk about it." He'd rather hear no right away than later. #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Back at #NarrativeBU to hear @elisaslow talk about his deep, intimate immersion reporting.
author: ErickTrickey

text: Find your voice? "Retitle that: trust your voice," says @DaveCullen. "It was always there." #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: Your process is frenetic. Do you enjoy this? A: Yes! says @DaveCullen. Have you heard “Don’t enjoy writing, enjoy having written?” he asks. “Get a new job! You’re not doing it right!” #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Can @DaveCullen leave out the Parkland killer as a character in a Parkland book? Yes, he says. "There are already plenty of books on killers. I already did that book. I wanted to write about an uprising."  #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: Q: Do we have the luxury of not caring about some characters? @DaveCullen answers: Oh, you have to. There were 2,000 students, 15,000 people directly involved in Columbine.  #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: But @davecullen also alternated the pain of the Columbine story with some humor & the few inspiring moments. Like in films, horror alternated with humor. #narrativeBU (3/3)
author: ErickTrickey

text: So @davecullen started a week before Columbine murders & introduced characters. Then the first murders, outside the school. Once the killers went inside, he shifted to point of view of those outside. Then aftermath + 4 flashbacks: what really happened inside. #narrativeBU (2/3)
author: ErickTrickey

text: How to structure a Columbine book? @DaveCullen decided he couldn't start with the murders -- too much like Saving Private Ryan, with climax, D-Day, in 1st minutes. He couldn't end with the murders -- seemed like "violence porn." #narrativeBU  (1/3)
author: ErickTrickey

text: Not every writer would use 10 protagonists like @DaveCullen did. Adam Hochschild once said at #NarrativeBU that a book should have 10 characters max (not 10 protagonists), a magazine article 3.
author: ErickTrickey

text: Wow, @DaveCullen wrote his Columbine book with 10 protagonists! He figured if Faulkner could have so many narrators in As I Lay Dying, he could too. #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: How do you tell a big story like the Columbine massacre, or gays in the military? asks @DaveCullen. Key Qs: What piece of it are you telling? What’s the beginning, middle, and end? What characters do you tell it through? #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: 6 C’s of narrative journalism: Curiosity, critical thinking, craft, creativity, courage, compassion. “You own these. An editor doesn’t give them to you. These are things you own and control.” @JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "If afraid of a story, find someone to help you. Don’t do this work alone. It shouldn’t be done alone." @JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
Compasson for self too. "Take care of yourself. Realize sometimes you will suck. 
Some day you just can’t make it be what you want. If you’re burned out, take a vacation." @JacquiB  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: 6. Compassion. "The myth of the uncaring journalist! Most journalists I know care more than almost everybody -- or they wouldn’t do the work. They care about the 1st Amendment, the people they write about, the people they write for." @JacquiB  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "Asking the feared question takes courage. The sensitive question, the challenging question, the question you think is rude." @JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
5. Courage. Not just physical courage. Bearing witness to very difficult things takes courage. Look without fog on your glasses at the worst things in the world. Tell them for those who don’t have the courage to go there.
 #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
Take risks in how you tell the story, or what stories to tell.
Things other reporters don’t see as a story, see if you can make them a story. 
Write postcards. Tell a story in 2½ square inches. Dare to try metaphors.
@JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: 4. Creativity. Because craft can become a formula. How do I break the rules? (Must know the rules first.) Take creative risks. Creativity is essentially problem-solving. @JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: 3. Craft. “Learn the craft. Study other forms," says @JacquiB . "I’m interested in country music, because it’s a tragedy in 3 acts. I’m interested in rap, because it’s political music. Movies are great for studying storytelling.”  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
The question journalists fail to ask most often is the simplest: How do you know?
Where did you get your information?  @JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Healthy, independent skepticism. You've got to figure out if someone isn’t telling you the complete story, says @JacquiB. It’s what makes the profession independent. #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: 2. Critical thinking. You can’t be naïve, says @JacquiB, re narrative journalism. Got to have your own bullshit detector. Listen for the lie. Listen for the spin. Interrogate numbers to see if they add up.  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: The only woman on an Antarctic expedition refused to talk about being the only woman. But when @JacquiB asked how she peed in an Antarctic tent, she answered.  Then she started talking about being a woman in Antarctica.  #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "When you ask questions of people, sometimes they won’t like it," says @JacquiB. "I’ve been called names, had doors slammed in my face. I apologize and move on." #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "The competition for assignments is fierce," says @JacquiB. "But if you can ask 6-7 questions about a news event, you can get the assignment." #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
If your curiosity is sincere, non-judgmental, open minded, it is greatest gift you can give other human beings. My notebook is a passport for my curiosity.
@JacquiB #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text:
At @JacquiB talk on The 6 C’s of Narrative Journalism.  
Curiosity: The #1 most important trait any journalist can have. #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Career advice for aspiring journalists from @farai? "People want people who can multi-task." She had her NYU students learn basic web design, audio editing, video editing, photography. #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: "Because of the wealth gap, a lot of students of color think they can't afford to be journalists," says @farai. "If we fix society," she says with a laugh, "hopefully the journalism problem will fix itself." #narrativebu
author: ErickTrickey

text: 2016 election coverage by @farai, on Trump voters: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/trumps-base-is-blue-collar-his-voters-looking-for-a-return-to-better-times/ … On black millennials: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/black-millennials-arent-united-behind-clinton-like-their-elders/ … #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: "I talked to a lot of Trump voters," says @farai. "The people I talked to had a lot of great insights into this country. The demonizing of Trump voters was a real problem in the last election."
author: ErickTrickey

text: Newsrooms should diversify before the 2020 elections, says @farai. More reporters from rural areas, more white working-class reporters, more reporters of color, more women in senior positions. #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: Diverse workplaces lead to higher returns, but also higher conflict, says @farai. In the good scenario, they work it out. In newsrooms, we don’t have good conflict resolution. #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: “People around the world want America to represent free speech, to represent democracy,” says @farai. “We can give the world true, important narratives.” “Sometimes do local reporting in nations where local reporters can’t do it without being killed.” #NarrativeBU
author: ErickTrickey

text: At #narrativeBU for the weekend.  Opening keynote from @farai, who's covered white supremacy & 25 years of elections.
author: ErickTrickey

text: Lou Reed Archive opens to the public today at @nypl. "Extensive papers, photographs, recordings ... spans Reed's creative life—from his 1958 Freeport High School band, the Shades, to his final performances in 2013."
author: ErickTrickey

text: Congrats, Jeannette, and good luck in the #CRMA finals!
author: ErickTrickey
